div.p: LOVE will finde out the Way. An Excellent COMEDY.
As it was Acted with great Applauſe, by Her Majeſties Servants, at the Phoenix in Drury Lane.
LONDON: Printed by Ja: Cottrel, for Samuel Speed, at the Signe of the Printing-Preſs in St. Paul's Church-yard. 1661.

list.item: Hartwel, a decay'd Gentleman, lover of Mrs. Frances.
Playfayre, Hartwel's kinſman and friend, lover of Hornet's Neece.
Lambert, another of Hartwel's friends, counterfeit King.
Three or four counterfeit Lords of Poland.
Horner, a great Uſurer, ſuitor to Mrs. Belamie.
Doctor of Phyſick to Hornet's Neece.
Startup, a clowniſh Gentleman, Hartwell's rival to Mrs. Frances.
Cloſe, an old truſtie Servant to Hartwel.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.item: Mrs. Frances, her daughter, Hartwell's Miſtreſs.

div.head: LOVE will finde out the Way.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: NAy let's not part ſo heavilie.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: For my own part, it does not trouble me ſo much,
That you have broke up houſe.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.l: And yet that ſticks in my ſtomack:
For hoſpitality went out of faſhion, with crop-doublets and codpieces.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: But I have worne out ſo many liveries, under your worſhpful father.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: My father had an office which brought in
A fair Revenew; I inherit but
His little land, whoſe annual profits will not
Encourage me to live at the ſame hight:
You may meet better fortunes; there's enough
Preferment in the world: my love and beſt
Aſſiſtance promiſe to your ſelves.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: I do not ſtand upon wages, ſir, I wont leave you.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Not leave me? how wilt thou live?

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.p:
Live? as other mortals do: yet I wont play the thief, that's a courſe may be taken, by which a man may aſcend the ladder of preferment; but I never lov'd to climb trees: I muſt confeſs I cannot cheat; I have heard there's a deviliſh deal of knowledge in the dice, and if men wont lend mony, they'll fetch it out o'th' bones: but it's beſt caſting in a Tavern, when the reckoning and the wine come up together. Some men have
a trick to ſpin out a living by't: there be many ſecret ways for Servingmen to live: alas 'tis not wages that does maintain all our tribe; eſpecially thoſe that have Miſtreſſes.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.p: But I am a batchelour.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.p: I pray let me be one of your buttons ſtill then; I am not half worne out; ye know what mould I am made of: I ever did you honeſt ſervice: and though the reſt of my fellowvermine can leave your falling houſe, I do not fear the rafters: By this hand I will wait upon you, though as ſome great mens ſervants, I live upon nothing but the air of commendation.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Well, ſince y'are ſo reſolute, ſtill attend me; the reſt
I here diſcharge: there's ſomewhat more, not worth the
Name of bounty; I will all
A happier entertainment.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.p: Heaven bleſs you, ſir, and there be no remedy.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: Farewell Cloſe.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.p: Pray give me leave to wet my lips with my old fellows; ſorrow makes a dry proverb; I muſt to a Tavern, and condole a quart with 'em.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.p: Meet me at Miſtreſs Bellamy's.—

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.p: I ſhall, ſir.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.p: How now, my Maſters?

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.p: You do not ſpeak to me, ſir? I am a ſervant ſtill: indeed, the caſe is alter'd with them; they are Maſters for want of a ſervice.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: Oh Maſter Playfaire!

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.p: It is not now as when Andrea liv'd.

sp.speaker: 3 Ser.
sp.p: This place was made for pleaſure, not for dearth.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: There was a time, when Mortals whetted knives.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.p: In time of yore, when men kill'd brutiſh beaſts.

sp.speaker: 3 Ser.
sp.p: Oh cruel butcher, whoſoere thou wert!

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.p: Do you not know what all this ſignifies?

sp.speaker: Play
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.p: My Maſter has given over houſe-keeping.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.p: Burglary, ſir, burglary; our young Maſter has broke up the Celler, and thrown the Kitchen out of the Hall-window.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.p: Nay, he has thrown the houſe out at window; it has a ſuperſcription already; and is directed to his next loving friend, that will pay the rent. You'll hardly know me, I have no fellow.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.p: Y'are very merry.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.p: He has caſheer'd a company.

sp.speaker: 3 Ser.
sp.p: And taken our good names from us.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.p: I know his nature is more noble; thou wert his groom.

sp.speaker: 3 Ser.
sp.p: Right, and now I am turn'd off, that good name is taken away; nay I am not company for his horſe.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.p: Graſs and Hay, we are all mortal.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.p: VVe may ſee what it is to be prick'd with provender; now we muſt bite o'th' bridle for't; all diſcharg'd.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.p: Certain?

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.p: Yes, certain of us are; for my Maſter only belongs to me: if you would ſpeak with him, you may overtake him, he's gone to Miſtreſs B llamies: in the mean time I give you to underſtand, that I Cloſe do ſtill follow my Maſter; have great hope to continue eating, though the reſt of my fellows here be blanks, and want filling.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.p: My Maſters, I have known you long; and though you be at loſs, in the confidence of your future honeſties, I will employ you in a device, which if it prove happy, mayreward you handſomly.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.p: And me too?

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.p: No, ſir, you are another mans ſervant; follow you your Maſter: if there be occaſion, I'll enquire for you: will you be faithful to a project of mine?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Doubt it not, ſweet Maſter Playfair, any thing.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.p: Follow me for your inſtructions: Farewel Cloſe, commend me to your Maſter.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.p: 'Buy Cloſe, honeſt Cloſe, we are blanks.—

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.p: Roul your ſelves up, and be drawn at the next lotterie: I wont leave my certainty, for all your projects, take my word for't; if your project fail, I ſhall find ſome of you in Pauls, watching behind a pillar, with a prayer that ſome gentleman will read the bedrol, and take pitty of a very ſerviceable fellow, to wait on him; but wants a cloak. Much good do ye with your Project.—

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Come widow, be rul'd by me; I know the world,
And I have ſtudied it theſe fifty years:
There's no man to be truſted.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Without good
Security, you mean.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: No young man, widow,
That talks and ſays he loves you, writes you verſes,
And ſwears he ſhall go hang himſelf unleſs
You pitty him: take me an old man.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Take you an old man: ſo.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Seaſon'd with care and thrift, not led away
By vitious converſations, nor corrupted
With pride and ſurfeit: one that knows the uſe
Of money? d'ye mark? the uſe.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yes, ſir; uſe upon uſe, you mean.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And dares not ſpend it prodigally; knowing
The principal end it was ordain'd to was,
To relieve neceſſity, and lay up
VVhat is above.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: To help the poor.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: You may,
If you be ſo diſpos'd; but 'tis as commendable
To give it in our will, to build an hoſpital,
And ſo our charity comes all together.
Beſides, who knows what tempeſts while we live
May riſe? 'tis wiſdom not to be without
A ſun-ſhine in our bags to quiet all:
I know you want no ſuitors in the City,
There be courtiers, great ones, with large titles,
Cold in their own eſtates, would warm themſelves
At your rich City-bonefire: there's no Alderman
Or wealthy Merchant, leaves his widow wealthy,
But ſtreight ſome noble blood, or luſtie kindred,
Claps in with his guilt coach and Flandrian Trotters,
And hurries her away to the next Counteſs:
No matter for corruption of their blood;
Some undone courtier made her husband rich,
And this new Lord receives it back again.
I would not have your ſtate thus eaten up
By caterpillers, but preſerv'd and made
Greater by marrying a diſcreet old man.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: And ſuch a one you ſhew your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: You happily interpret me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I will not tell you till we meet again,
What operation your good counſel has upon me.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: She inclines; 'tis your good nature.
I'm plain Hornet, and have no tricks; I'll tell you all
My fault, I'm given much to gather wealth;
No kindred, only a neece, left to my truſt
With a great portion; one that is never like to marry.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: She never thriv'd ſince ſhe came to me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I eaſily believe it.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Melancholy
VVill kill her, and yet I purſue all ways
That promiſe her delight; I ſpare no coſt
Of phyſick; what her Doctor ſays, is done.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: 'Tis lovingly perform'd.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: VVhat's he?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: A Gentleman that bears my daughter much affection.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Sure I have ſeen him.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Maſter Hartwel.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Oh he's a begger, or muſt be very ſhortly.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Have you his lands in morgage?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Not yet, not yet, but he'll want money too:
His kinſman Playfair keeps him company;
Take heed on him.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: He has good breeding.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Hang breeding, 'tis unluckie:
They never keep their ſtate that have too much on't:
Counſel your daughter, Miſtreſs Bellamy,
To throw him off.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You direct well.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: VVhen we are married, I'll provide a match
For her.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You have care on us.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: It will become me.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Is a ſuiter to thy mother.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: He would be ſuch a thing, were I not happy
In ſuch a jolly father in law.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: A looks like ſome caſt money-bag, that had given up
The ſtuffing, and for want of uſe grown mouldy:
He dares not keep a fire in's Kitchen, leſt
VVarming his hands, which rather look like gloves ſo tan'd,
And thin, he lets 'em ſcorch, and gather into a heap.
I do not think he ever put off his clothes:
He would run mad at ſight of's own anatomie.
That ſuch a wretch ſhould have ſo vaſt a wealth!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I'll not be his Neece,
For all his fortune.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: I preſume
Your mother is more noble, then to encourage
Him in his courtſhip: her eſtate would mix
Not well with his ill-gotten wealth, extorted
From widows and from orphans: nor will all
His plenty keep his ſoul one day from famine:
'Tis time ill ſpent, to mention him; let's talk
Of ſomething elſe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Of love again,
Whoſe flames we equally divide.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Your table
Is a devourer, and they ſhut up doors
Firſt, that keep open houſe and entertainments:
This Lord is feaſted, and that young Ladies ſweet tooth
Muſt have a banquet: t'other old
Madam with ne'er a tooth, muſt have ſome marchpane
Coral to rub her gums withal: theſe are
Vain and ridiculous expences.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: 'Tis not too late to thrive.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: This room has too rich furniture, and worſe
Hangings would ſerve the turn; if I may be
Worthy to counſel, pictures are too
Superfluous, of this and t'other maſters
Doing: hang Michael Angelo and his oyls;
If they be given, y'are the more excus'd
To let 'em hang; but have a care you let not
Appear either in Arras or in Picture,
The ſtorie of the prodigal, 'twill fright
Young gentlemen from ſpending of their portions
That come to viſit you; whoſe unbounden Riots
May enrich you, with their forfeited eſtates:
I have a thouſand precepts more.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: But d'ye not
Think all this while of Heaven?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: 'Tis in my wealth.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Or hell?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: A fable to fright fools and children; but
I cannot ſtay, my Scrivener does expect me;
I'll viſit you another time, ſweet widow,
And give you more inſtructions.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Spare your labour,
I ſha'not practice theſe in haſte, and muſt
Declare, theſe precepts make not for your welcome.
My patience was no vertue all this while.
If you but think you have a ſoul, repent:
Your rules I am not covetuous to follow;
I dare not love 'em.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Live, and be undone then;
You'll tell me another tale hereafter, widow.—

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: If it pleaſe you, here's a letter from Maſter Startup
The Country-Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: What's he?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: A freſh fuitor of my Nurſes commendations.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: Heaven deliver me! What have I ſeen? ſure this
Thing was once at Bartholomew-Fire, or ſuch another
Furr'd Baboon for all the world: do'ſt know him?
And yet why do I ask? the devil would hardly
Take acquaintance with him.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: 'Tis maſter Hornet the great Uſurer.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: Nay then my wonder's over; and the devil himſelf
Be ſuch another, they may be ſworn brothers, and divide
Hell betwixt 'em.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Who's that you talk on, ſirrah?

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: Of the diſeaſe that heaven be thank'd has left you,

sp.speaker: Hornet.
sp.l: But ſir, I have news for you.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: I'll hear it in the Garden.—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Do you love this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I hope you move not this as if you doubted;
I took him firſt upon your character,
Into my good opinion.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: But things alter;
What then I thought him, I delivered you,
Nor ſince hath he deſerv'd a leſs eſteem
In his own perſon: but the circumſtance
Is not the ſame; his fortune I have examined,
Which riſes not to ſuch a value I
Did apprehend it; it becomes my care,
Being at one gift to depart with thee
And my eſtate, to look for one whoſe purſe
May carry a proportion.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Make me not
Imagine you would wed me to a heap
Of ſhining duſt, a golden bondage.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Nor to penury:
His birth and education are not unworthy, he's hanſome too:
But be not govern'd by your eye too much;
Children and age purſue us, and ſome ſtorms
Hover about our frail conditions:
All theſe muſt be provided for: they are not
Kiſſes will make our winters warm; and therefore
Confident of your obedience, I propound
Another to your beſt thoughts.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Oh my unhappyneſs!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: A Country gentleman of ſpreading fortunes,
Young too, and not uncomely; for his breeding,
It was not ſpun the fineſt: but his riches
Able to guild deformity, and make
Even want of wit a vertue, when your life
Renders it ſelf more ſweet by your command:
His name is Maſter Startup, expected
Our gueſt to morrow; that's his letter, read it.
This may ſeem ſtrange, while it is coming toward you:
But when diſcretion comes to examine what
A fruitful conſequence attends it, you
Will thank me for't.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: But with your pardon, mother:
Although I could diſpence with my own thoughts,
And frame them to obedience, will this change
Be for your honour, or mine own? when ſuch,
When ſuch a noble gentleman ſhall boaſt he had
With your conſent my liking? or admit
That which we gain by riches of the ſecond,
Seem to authorize, and may juſtifie
The act with ſome: How can it cure the wound,
Which the poor heart that loves ſhall find too ſoon,
When 'tis neglected, and ſo cruelly,
Where it hopes for cheriſhing? Oh think
How you did love my father, firſt; and be
Now gentle to your daughter: your eſtate
Is above needy providence, or grafting
Into a new ſtock; it does grow already
Fair from his own root, and does want no piecing;
Nor are the means of Hartwel ſo contemptible.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: No more: when y'ave conſider'd well, you'll ſhape
Another anſwer; i'th' mean time diſpoſe
Your countenance to entertain this new
And able lover: leave the ſatisfaction
Of Hartwel to my care; he's here, to your chamber.—

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: I know not what's the trick on't, nor themſelves yet,
But he has a project to employ 'em in.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: I wiſh it well—But do you work your ſelf
Into the opinion of the Nurſe, ſhe is
The Major Domo, and has all the intelligence.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: Let me alone, I'll work her, ſir, like wax,
To print what form you pleaſe upon her; 'tis
A loving croan to me already:
I'll ſpeak her fair, and in my drink may marry her.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Maſter Hartwel?

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: About your buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: There is a buſineſs, ſir, which I muſt open,
And you perhaps will wonder at.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: You prepare my attention.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You do love my daughter,
At leaſt I think ſo.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: If you knew my heart,
You might be confident; in her I ſum
All my deſires on earth.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Be not ſo fixt.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: How, Lady?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: When you have heard me out, perhaps you'll find
Your conſent eaſie to call back a promiſe
Made to your diſadvantage.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: I acknowledge
This makes me wonder; pray interpret Lady,
And ſpeak a language I may underſtand;
I love your daughter.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: But muſt never glory
In the reward which you expect ſhould be
Her marriage.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: In the number of my actions
There is not one that's guilty of ſo much
Offence to you, that I ſhould be ſo ſoon
Loſt to your favour.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Have no thought ſo poor,
You can deſerve leſs; my opinion
Is ſicher laden with your merit then before.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Now
I fear again, this violent turn of praiſe,
Makes me ſuſpect my ſtate: if I be fallen,
Teach me to know my treſpaſs.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I ne'er look'd
With ſo cleer eyes into your worth; and 'twere
A ſin to general goodneſs to delay
The free reſign of that, your truth may challenge.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: If this be meant, pray pardon my miſtake
Of ſomething went before: love made me fear
You ſaid I never ſhould enjoy your daughter
In marriage, which your ſelf ſo late incline to.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: And muſt again repeat, you ſha' not call
Her bride.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Can you forbid this happineſs, and love me?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yes, ſo dearly, Hartwel, I preſent
My ſelf to thy affections.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: You amaze me, and fright my underſtanding.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Does the name
Of widow ſound diſpleaſing? I have learn'd
Already to obey; my years are not
So many with a thought to freeze your blood;
I wear no print of time, deep on my brow,
Nor have my hairs the innocence of age:
Gentlemen active, and of noble birth,
Think no diſhonour to beſeech my love,
And if they flatter not, commend my perſon:
Adde unto this my wealth, no narrow fortune,
And without competition, my daughter
Depending on my love, whoſe portion muſt
Flow from my bounty, or be nothing: make
A ſober apprehenſion of this Tender,
And think I was not able to ſuppreſs
Theſe flames of love increaſe ſtill by your vertues:
This minute quit all hopes of Frances,
Whoſe mother will admit no Rival; 'tis
Within your own election to be happy:
My love accepted comes with fair attendance;
Deny'd, you haſten your own exile; think on't,
To morrow ſometime, I'll expect your anſwer.—

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: What have I heard? Was it her Mother ſpake thus?
As Pilgrimes by miſtake of ſome ſmall path,
Having told many weary ſteps, at night
When their hopes flatters 'em they are not far
From ſome kind entertainment, finde themſelves
Loſt in a wilderneſs; ſo am I miſerable:
Thus Love delights to wound and ſee us bleed,
He were a gentle god to kill indeed.—

div.head: Actus Secundus.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: WO'd thou wo'dſt ſpeak a good word for me: I am
Weary of my indentures: I like a fool was in good hope
He ſhould have married Miſtreſs Frances.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: He's a begger; ſhe his wife? no, Maſter Startup
Is the man, the man of lands and mony.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: Into whoſe ſervice if I could wriggle my ſelf, a
Word of thy mouth does it.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: I muſt tell you by the way, he is little better then a
fool.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: The fitter for her husband, and my maſter.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: Y'are i'th' right, he's innocent to your hands, and
You may ſoon come to nonage his eſtate

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: VVhich if I do, thou ſha't want no petticoats,
All's thine own.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: VVhat?

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: VVhy all that I can beg, borrow or ſteal from him:
sp.p: VVhat ſhould he do with ſo much riches? I'd perſwade my young Miſtriſs, after the firſt year, to put him to his penſion: he ſhould pay for's diet; and after a month or two, for every time he comes aloft. Hang him, Cuckow-pintle.

sp.speaker: Nurſ.
sp.p: Nay, let her begin betimes, if ſhe mean to rule the roaſt: I'll give her Documents; and be you ſure you ſtick cloſe to your Miſtriſs; there's ſomething to be got that way.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: Excellent Verges!
How I do love thy documents! I but he's here,
I'll not be ſeen with thee; farewell:
At night we'll talk the reſt over a ſack-poſſet.—

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: I will uſe this advantage to over-hear a little.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: You tell me ſtrange things; is it poſſible
The widow her ſelf loves you?

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: VVould I had reaſon but to ſuſpect.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Turn Colt again; this love will kill's all:
And can ſhe make no choice, but where her daughter
Has the ſame longing? not her dancing days done yet?
VVhy there's no remedy, you muſt love her.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: How? and violate my faith to Frances?

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Thou wilt not be ſo much an infidel,
To think I mean thou ſhouldſt forſake the wench.
Tell me the mother a fine tale of love,
Print kiſſes on her paper-lip, and hug
Her reverend body; any thing but lie with her:
VVrite ſonnets on the ivorie tooth afore;
Swear ſhe does cough diſtinctly; get a rime
To bleſs her when ſhe ſneezes, and cry up
The method of her noſe, which ſweats and falls
So perpendicular; admire the motion
Of her blew eyes that look three ways at once:
Praiſe her above thy reaſon, or her daughter,
And then ſhe will believe, thou maiſt be mad for her.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Is this the way to do me good? ſhe comes
Too faſt upon me already.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Let her flie to thee,
Thou maiſt clip her wings the ſooner, this ſecures thee:
Should you hold off, and play the modeſt creature,
Nay but deny as maids do, when they love it,
And bending of your hams cry, No forſooth,
Profeſs your ſelf, with coxcomb-like civility,
You are not worthy of her carnal favours,
She may believe it; and in very ſpight
Marry her daughter to a Citizen;
Or ſhould you be ſo mad to think to win her
To your firſt choice, withholding your paſſions
For Miſtreſs Frances, complaining how Don Cupid
Hath ſacrific'd your heart; you may go hang your ſelf:
Go to the Barbers, let him firk your hair up,
And ſpend his powder; waſh your ſullen face,
And ſtarch your infant, upper-lip to look
Like one that would run deſperate on a widow.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: Here's pretious conſpiracie!

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: This is the way:
At leaſure, you may tell your natural Miſtreſs,
Like Jove you have but put another ſhape on
To cheat the Beldame Juno.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: Foul-mouth raſcal, I'm glad I know your plot.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: I apprehend, th'aſt given me good counſel:
I'll watch the firſt occaſion to aſſure,
I have prefer'd her in my heart already.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: I'll conjure up a croſs plot, and that quickly,
Shall mar your mirth, and pay your fine diſſembling;
Are you ſo cunning, my love gameſter?—

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: So I'll take my leave then, y'ave no other ſervice
To uſe my ſtay: I have a project, Hartwel,
That muſt not be neglected.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: May not communicate?

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Thou art ingag'd to wait
Upon thine own affair, or I ſhould trouble thee
To be an actor in't; thou know'ſt Hornet.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: He is a ſutor to the widow, and
After the rate we caſt the plot, my rival.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: I'll rival him; he ſmothers a poor gentlewoman
At home with Sea-coal, and allowes her no
More light then ſerves to read in painted cloth,
The expoſition of the harlots ſtorie.
Hartwel, I love her; and before her Father
Dyed, we exchang'd our honeſt hearts; 'tis here
To free her from that ſlavery ſhe lives in
Under the iron-hearted Jaylor, elſe
I ſhall repent my aim; he broods upon
Her portion, but I have a trick may ſpoil
His hatching of young bags; thou ſhalt know all
Hereafter; to the widow, Hartwel: I am
For ſtate-affairs; be faithful, and pray for me.
We muſt be bold: farewell, if ſomething hit,
We'll laugh in ſpight of Dives and the Devil.—

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: This is the thing, ſir, that muſt carry away
The garland; they have given him a cup or two
Of ſack, and he has the prettieſt humour,
He does ſo whiſtle out his complement:
He wears his feather like the captain of
A country team, and would become a horſe-coller
Rarely; I do not think, but were he put to't
With little ſwitching, he would draw the Cart well.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.p: Sweet Lady, I am your humble ſervant; 'tis well known what I am, where I live; my father dyed ſince I was of age, and left me a younger brothers portion.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: A younger brother?

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.p: Sweet Lady, I know what you would ſay, my father had no more children; but I ſpeak modeſtly of my eſtate; I have land enough for two or three wives; I have a horſe in Town; your daughter ſhall ride behind me; Sweet Lady, did you ever ſee the country?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What country, ſir?

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.p: VVhy, any country living: ſweet Lady, I am your humble ſervant; if you love hawking, hunting, or drinking, there be good fellows will bear you company. Is there any good Tobacco in London?

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.p: Virginia-Tobacco grows here.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.p: Sweet ſir, I am your humble ſervant, you ſeem to be a gentleman will fetch me a pipe: there's half a piece, if I be not troubleſome: perhaps, ſweet Lady, you do not love it: if it offend you, let it alone.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.p: A very pretious widgen.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.p: La, la, la, lere.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You dance well, ſir.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.p: He has a ſtrong back, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.p: Sweet Lady, is this your daughter?

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.p: Ask that queſtion now?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I was her mother, ſir.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.p: That may be too; what gentleman is that? ſweet ſir, I am your humble ſervant likewiſe.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.p: You are too humble, ſir, to ſtoop ſo low; It would become my duty.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.p: Sweet ſir, 'tis all one; a leg or an arm is not caſt away among friends: I am a Country-Gentleman, all the world knows; ſweet ſir, I have no buſineſs in Town.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I thought you came to ſee my daughter.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.p: That may be too; ſweet Lady, pray excuſe me, I honour your fair daughter; for I know as well as another, what belongs to a gentlewoman: ſhe's not the firſt ſweet Lady I have lov'd i'th' way of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.p: Were you ever married?

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.p: Sweet ſir, no; all men are not alike.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.p: For ſome are fools.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Sweet ſir, I do confeſs it;
But wit is never good till it be bought,
They ſay; there are very good wits in Town,
I have brought money a purpoſe with me to buy;
If any will ſell me a good pennyworth,
I'll give him a hundred pieces, becauſe
I would carry a little down into the Country.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Is there a dearth in your Country?

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Sweet ſir, there's plenty.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: Of wild-oats; I heard you had much to ſow ſtill.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: My Tenants have, ſweet ſir, but 'tis all one;
This Lady ſhall be Lord o'the Soil: I wo'nt
Give any man ſix pence for a buſhel of mony.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: Oh brave ſack!

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: I am a gentleman, my Father was a Yeoman;
But that's all one, ſweet Lady: howſoever I am yours,
And every limb is at your ſervice;
My hands ſhall walk, my feet ſhall run.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Away, away.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: By this bright gold they ſhall.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: He keeps his oath.—

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Not run?
My Grand-father was a Noblemans Footman, and
Indeed he run his Country; my Father did
Outrun the Conſtable.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: And he, ſweet Lady,
Being his fathers iſſue, muſt run naturally.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: If I live.—

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: He'll run himſelf out of all.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Not run,
Sweet Lady? if you have occaſion to uſe me,
I wo'nt ſtand upon my feet.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: No, ſir?

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Nay I'll ſtand upon my head, ſweet Lady,
To do you courteſie.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: Then his heels were upwards.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Pleaſe you, a ſorry dinner ſtays for you.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Sweet Lady, I am your ſervant; will this Gentleman
dine with us?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I'll prevail with Maſter Hartwel.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: D'ye know what you have done? he's rival
Miſtreſs; why, d'ye mean to invite him?

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Sweet ſir, I invite nobody; if you love
Any body here.—

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Sweet ſir,
I ſha'not take it kindly, I do not uſe
To quarrel.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: When y'are beaten, ſir, he ſha'not wrong you:
Then lay lay him o'er the face.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Sweet ſir,
'Tis dinner-time, fair Lady.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Maſtert Hartwel?—

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: I had a great mind to have him beaten;
But he's not valiant at meals: would I
Were hired to beat him hanſomly after dinner,
And make him thank me for't; I'll have ſome plot
Upon your pretious body, my ſweet ſir.—

div.stage: Enter Hornet and Doctor, Playfaire's Brother.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: You ell me wonders, Doctor.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: I have cur'd
Her melancholy; but ſhe's o't'other ſide
Now extream merry, dance and ſing, all air.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: 'Tis ſtrange methinks, nothing but extremities:
Good Maſter Doctor, could you not have par'd
Her t'other leaden humour?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Sir, I could not
Kill the malignity of her melancholy
Another way: extreamities muſt be cur'd
With extreme applications: my next work
Shall be to abate this levity of her brain,
To qualifie her ſpleen, ſir, by degrees;
So ſtate her body in that modeſt temper
She was poſſeſt of.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I complain'd before
Of quietneſs; now ſhe's all noiſe and madneſs,
By your deſcription.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: You muſt have patience
A month or ſo, ſhe is not mad but merry;
Some ſtange figaries: you muſt underſtand,
I have open'd, ſir, her fancie, wherein lay
All her imaginations confus'd,
And of a heap, ſmother'd for want of vent;
And now the ſpirits that were impriſon'd
Ruſh out, which cauſeth all her faculties
Before oppreſt, to exerciſe themſelves
So unexpectedly, as the agitation of her tongue
Soon will manifeſt: ſhe's here.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Unkle, how does your body? you appear
As lean as Lent: I've a great mind to dance
About a Maypole; ſhall we?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: She is mad.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: This Doctor has ſo tickled me,
I cannot chuſe but laugh; ha, ha, ha:
Unkle, if you'll procure a diſpenſation
To marry me your ſelf, de duct the charges
Out of my portion: I'll have no other
Husband; I could affect an old man now
With all my heart.

q.l: An old man with a bed full of bones,
Turn to me hony and give me a kiſs, &c.

sp.l: Unkle, when did you put on a clean ſhirt?
Not ſince your wife dyed; that was a pretty ſhift.
Indeed I dream'd o'th' devil the laſt night;
They ſay 'tis good luck: d'ye not know him, Unkle?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I know the devil!

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: He's a fine old gentleman,
And ſomething like you; no ſuch bugbear as
The world imagines; you and he'll keep houſe
Together one day: but you'll burn ſea-coal too,
To ſave charges, and ſtink the poor ſouls ſo.
Shall we go hunt to day? I long to ſtrike
A Deer; pray lend me a Croſs-Bow, will you, ſir?
I'll pay you uſe for't.

l.hi: And ſtill ſhe cry'd, Shepherd ſhoot home.

sp.l: Unkle, you are not merry, I pray laugh
A little; imagine y'ad undone a widow,
Or turn'd an orphan begging now: ha, ha!
How many Churches, 'faith, will you build when
You dye? I'll have ſix Bells in every Steeple,
And they ſhall go to th'tune of Turn again
Whittington, who let out his land
For nine lives, 'cauſe it came in by a Cat.
Die Unkle, die, at all adventures.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Why does ſhe talk of dying? ſhe's ſtark mad;
Could you not put into the next receipt,
Something to make her ſleep well?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Opium.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: In a good quantity.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: I could ſo proportion it,
She ſhould not wake at all to trouble you:
I did it for a Merchants wife laſt week,
Which lov'd a Knight. A great man not long ſince,
Was weary of his Counteſs; and I cur'd him
So artificially of the diſeaſe.—

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: She hears.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: But collects nothing, yet her ſences
Are ſcattered.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: You ſhall give toward the building
Of Pauls—Nothing: ſee the mony firſt
Laid out that's given already; it were much
Sin to bely the dead; but 'tis no matter,
You may be as famous, ſir, for pulling down
The Pariſh; for the Church will fall of't ſelf,
Why did they put the poor fellow in priſon?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Whom? what fellow?

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Why the Corn-cutter,
Poor gentleman he meant the City
No harm; his feet were weary, and that made him
In every ſtreet cry out, Have ye any Corns
I' your head or toes?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: Which is Maſter Hornet?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Ha! with me?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: A word, ſir.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Prethee what's he? he comes to borrow money
On his wives wedding-ring, or his childs whiſtle now:
You may ſee by his noſe, he has no land, he looks
As hungry as a Hawk: what do you dream on?
Or what Ladies tympany is your next cure?
Or whoſe ſtate body muſt be rectified
With your quaint gliſter?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: There is no diſputing, I muſt attend you.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I am ſent for by a Purſivant: the King?
Alas, I am undone, I never ſaw him;
How ſhould he know me? a poor wretch.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Is't not
Some complaint? think.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: That's my fear, there be
Too many Knaves i'th' world; and a man cannot
Grow rich, but one ſtate-ſurgeon or other
Muſt practice on his purſe: before this Lord
One veyn is opened, in t'other Court
So many ounces he muſt bleed again.
Let me ſee: all the treaſon I committed,
Is, that I ſhifted houſes; for I took
Delight to cozen him of his ſubſidies.
I live obſcurely, to avoid
Taxations: I never paid the Church
Her ſuperſtitious tythes, nor come to trouble
Sermons, for fear of homilies before,
That beg for burning.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Why how now, Uncle? Is your Scrivener broke,
You talk ſuch lamentation?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I am ſent for
To the King, Neece, and ſhall be made a beggar,
As I was born: I ſee my Chattels ſeiz'd;
This Cheſt is ranſack'd, and that bag deflour'd;
My dore ſeal'd up; and with this hungry meſſenger
I am already marching to the Fleet.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Nay, and you be at that ward, I leave you.
Maſty, farewel: pray do not bite my Uncle
Too hard; and ſo I leave you all to th' mercy
Of the Bear-Garden.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Beſt make faſt her chamber.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: I, I, curſed Dog: and

l.hi: Set a thouſand guards about her,
Love will find out a way.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Wo'nt ſome money qualifie your haſte,
And give him time to appear?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: Good Mr. Doctor,
Teach your Apothecary: Galen nor
Hippocrates can perſwade me from my duty.
Will you go, ſir? or ſhall I certifie?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Go! I muſt go.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Have comfort, ſir: this cloud
May ſoon blow over.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Yes, when I'm blown up:
I read impriſonment in his very looks,
And all my gold confiſcate.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: I heard her ſay, ſhe would walk up to her chamber:
The trick was but to teach him whither he
Should follow, who as nimbly apprehended,
To acquaint her with his new affections.
I did this for your good, that Mrs. Francis,
Whom I'll ſend preſently to you, may be
Convinc'd in Hartwel's falſhood, and tranſplant
Her love on you.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: This will be excellent!
So ſhall we ſtrangle him in his own nooſe,
And he ne'er know who hurt him.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: I'll looſe no time, you know my inſtructions.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: I almoſt had forgot; there is a caſt
Of angels more.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: They are not caſt away.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: If thou doſt fear they'll drown, Nurſe, I can give
Thee lighter, I have ſome want weight.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: If you have an evil angel about you, your buſineſs
will thrive the better, when 'tis departed.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: There, Mother of the Maids.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: Now all the good ones wait upon your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Theſe things that go to and again, muſt have
Their fees, they'll never ſpeak in our cauſe elſe.
Aha, ſweet ſir! we'll be too cunning for you.
She's come already: ſweet Lady, how do ye do?
Y'are melancholy, you ſhall have ſome cauſe
If I can help you to't; if you be ſad
Becauſe I love you as I do, be merry
Again: there's no man cares a button for you
Beſides my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I am very ill befriended.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: You are deceiv'd in ſome body, and me too;
I love you I confeſs, but how? not for
Want of a Miſtreſs; I came not a woing
For ſuch neceſſity, although you have
So little wit, to believe ſomething that
I know concerning t'other party.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Tell me, have you opinion, ſweet Lady,
That any man beſides my ſelf does love
This face of yours? but underſtand, I'll mak't
Appear, and preſently.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: VVhy I dare ſhew my face:
My glaſs cannot ſo much deceive me, ſir:
I ſhou'd be aſham'd it ſhould appear.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Nay I am
For that, a your ſide; d'ye conceive me right?
A worſe face will become the Country, and
Shew well enough at the muſtering; but that
You ſhould be ſuch an aſs.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: This is plain Courtſhip.

sp.speaker: Start.
sp.l: Be ſure you underſtand me, and you do not
Repent it, I dare give one of theſe ears.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You do not threaten me?

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Underſtand me right,
But if I do, and will threaten you agen,
Becauſe you ſhall live long to ſee your folly,
And what a Coxcomb you have made your ſelf,
To love a man that is a ſuitor to
Your mother: ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: VVhom do you mean?

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: E'en Mr. Hartwel:
Are you ſuch a buzzard
You cannot ſee't? then you ſhall hear it: ſtep
Behind theſe hangings, and he'll juſtifie it.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: I have conſider'd perfectly; and if
You will vouchſafe me hearing, dare pour forth
My heart, which full of love renders it ſelf
To your acceptance: I acknowledge, Lady,
My paſſions are but young, for tould I hope
You ſhould with ſo much favour look upon me?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: But may I credit this?

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: But to ſuſpect,
Were an injuſtice to my faith, which looks
Upon your vertue with as much religion
As love is able to receive: your age
Hath ſtruck a reverence into my eye;
And what you want of youth and ſpring upon you,
Your wiſdom richly ſatisfies. Thoſe characters
Which time hath written on your careful forehead,
Are but his envie, and your ornament,
VVhen it ſhall come to paſs by your example,
That youth ſhall be eſteem'd an infancy,
And women never ripe for love or marriage
VVithout your age upon them; 'tis a fault
That men not guided by the tract of reaſon,
But heat and wantonneſs of blood, run giddy
To ſeal ſuch weighty covenants; better 'twere
The world ſhould end in our Virginitie,
Then ſpin it ſelf more length, by inconſiderate
And haſty marriages.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Have you already
Retriv'd the affection which purſu'd my daughter?
Shall I believe no ſeeds of love remain,
VVhich may grow up and ripen with repentance?
For this exchange I do allow you, ſir,
The conſideration of my fortune, which
Might in it ſelf incline you to accept me.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: That is but an attendant, as you uſe it,
I muſt confeſs a welcome one, although
The mind is the firſt beauty which true love
Aſpires to, when 'tis waited on with perſon
And an eſtate; it comes with greater priviledge
To win upon's: I do not wiſh you, Lady,
Raſhly believe what I profeſs, but meaſure
My ſervice by the tryal; I'll expect,
And write your ſmiles a competent reward,
Till time and your demand demonſtrate me,
Although not equal to your full deſervings,
Yet one that has ambition to be thought
Not too unworthy.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: And I gueſs ere long,
Such an occaſion will preſent it ſelf.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Till then have Hartwel in your loving memory,
Who wiſhes no more happyneſs of life
Then to be call'd yours.—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: VVhat have I underſtood?

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Will you believe me another time, ſweet Lady?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: It is not he, ſome devil does out cozen us,
And mock our ſence, with theſe phantaſtick bodies.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Nay 'tis the man, I hope you'll be converted,
And think a Country Gentleman worth favour
That brought you to this knowledge; I deſerve.—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: My curſes for this black diſcovery:
VVhereas before 'twas not impoſſible
In time I might be brought to pitty thee;
Henceforth I'll look upon thee as my ſins,
And beg as much forgiveneſs, that I knew thee.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Nay, but d'ye hear?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Die quickly, and be forgotten.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: This is very fine, ſweet Lady!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: My mother! Oh my fate! ſee me no more,
And I'll forgive thee.—

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Is't come to this? I ſee
I am a fool, and there's no remedy —

div.head: Actus Tertius.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: Fie, fie, I am aſham'd on you, a Gentleman
Of your high promiſing, and be put off
So ſlightly?

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: VVhy Nurſe? what would you have me do?

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.p: Do? I would have you do — ſomething; a man of your ability, and cannot turn and wind a woman?

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: You would not have wiſhed me
To have put her to't behind the hangings?

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: You ſhould have been round with her.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: I was round
With her; I call'd her aſs, I think, and coxcomb:
Unleſs I ſhould have given her the lye,
And call'd her whore, I could not be more round with her.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: I do not mean that way.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: And ſhe call'd me,
I think, her—

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: VVhat?

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Why no worſe then all her ſins; heaven forgive her,
She has the more to anſwer; nay ſhe did
Not ſtick to bid me dye too, in that deſperate
Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: Come, you ſhall take another courſe.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: What ailes my Maſters ſweet-heart? is ſhe frighted?
I met and ask'd her for my Maſter, and
She turn'd tail like a hound had loſt the ſent:
There's ſomething in the wind: my three pil'd worſhipful,
Are you there, with my Lady o'the larder?
Now in that poſture, do not they two look like
A fine Brick-Houſe and a Thatch'd-Barn i'th' Country,
Laying their heads together? without doubt
Some pretious conſultation: what poeſie
Will fit his joynt ring, or how many yards
Of Holland without ſeaming-lace will make
His Miſtreſs ſmock: they have ſpied me.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: Come hither; nay he's faithful, and one that
Has a deſire to ſerve you: you may truſt him.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: Your worſhip may truſt me abed w'ye; I
Have had an itch this great while, ſir, a kinde
Of longing, to be one of your appurtenances;
I have ſome faults, and I'll confeſs 'em: I have
A humour now and then when I am asked
A queſtion, to tell truth, though I be chid for't;
And I do not love blows: you may ſooner beat
My brains out, then a word of flattery:
I cannot batten upon commendation,
Without my wages, nor be valiant
Upon ſmall beer; I am not overmuch
Given to be drunk, but I've a trick o'th' Dutchman,
To do your buſineſs as well drunk as ſober:
I have not impudence enough to pimp
For you; but I have a gift, I can ſay nothing
As well as your chaplain; I ſuck'd ſecreſie
From mine own mother, once a baudy Mid-wife:
I was born upon Shrove-Tueſday, and ſhall be
Now and then given to rebellion:
My fleſh will once a year riſe at a chambermaid,
If none ſuch take me down; I ſhall in malice
And deep revenge, fling out upon May Day
Among the Apprentices without fear or wit:
If you chance to be arreſted, I dare kill
Any thing, but a Sergeant; he's lapt
In law, a wearing ſtronger far then buff:
If any gentleman ne'er ſo much provok'd,
Prick him between the ſeams, or knock his brains out,
Which is the ſurer way (for moſt a theſe
Vermine, would fain be kill'd) he is ſure to take
His leave at the Towns end; his breakfaſt is
Tyed up, and ſtays for him, neer my Lord Mayors
Banquetting houſe, made for the City-progreſs.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: I like his humour.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: Nay he has a ſconce,
And ſhall be of our counſel; afterward,
Your worſhip may entertain him: Look you Cloſe,
There is a plot to help this Gentleman
At night, when they are abed: and if you went
To bed betimes, to avoid ſuſpition,
'Twere never the worſe; I'll ſay you are not well:
D'ye mark? this honeſt Gentleman ſhall be
Let into Mrs. Frances bedchamber.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: Without her knowledge?

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: You ſhall only attend
To give him notice from me when to come,
And watch about the houſe, he may get off
Without diſcovery; this is all.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: So, ſo, I ſha' not keep the door.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: I can do that.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: Let me alone to give you notice who
Stirs about houſe.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: Away, 'tis Maſter Hartwel,
We'll not be ſeen together,
Go your ways.—

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: A fooliſh knave and baud, that do want nothing
But carting; I would ſooner ſee that Tryumph
Then all the Pageants a day after Simon
And Jude, when the fine City goes a feaſting.
Oh ſir, I have news; yes, they are gone, brave news,
Your gentlewoman can hold out no longer:
This night there will be a ſtratagem; the governeſs
Old madam Humpeapampe, the Nurſe, has promis'd
To admit the Country Gentleman, when all
Are abed, into her chamber; yes, your Miſtriſſes:
I'm o'the plot to lie perdue, and give
The word if any fire-lock approach;
The reſt imagine: if he have not art to
Perſwade her to the feat with him, yet there
Be tricks, and he may be ſurpriz'd i'th' chamber,
And ſhe may be compell'd to marry him, in
Her own defence: there have been ſuch devices.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Does ſhe conſent?

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: She is betray'd to't, Sir.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Thou wo't not be ſo baſe.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: And I had meant it,
I ne'er had told you this: can you make uſe
Of this intelligence?

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Th'art my honeſt ſervant.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: I promis'd to be his.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: I have it, canſt
By any means procure me but his cloathes?

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: With eaſe: he'll go to bed betimes, to void
Suſpition, that's a part of our deſigne.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: I could not wiſh a happier opportunity,
To try how ſhe affects this gaudy fool,
And cleer my faith to her; which her mothers watch
Will not permit: ſhe has I fear obſerv'd
My new familiarity with the mother,
Which I'm compell'd to, and muſt cure this way:
Fail me not, Cloſe, and propound thy own
Reward.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: Tell me your purpoſe, and let my wit
Diſpoſe of him.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Proſper me Love in this.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: And you fall to your prayers
With good Love look about us, I ſhall ſuſpect
You will not thrive: you ſhould go to a wench
As gentlemen fall to Oyſters, without ceremony,
Or ſaying grace; devotion will ſpoil all.—

div.stage: Enter Playfaire and Doctor his brother.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Right as an arrow.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Witty engineer:
But was ſhe taken with the plot?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: I was
Compell'd to frame an outſide of a reaſon,
Leſt her own mirth ſhould play the traytor with us,
Her ſpleen was ſo dilated; he believes
She's mad: which change makes for us.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: And he that you employ'd, the Purſivant,
Shew'd ſuch a ſurly raſcal, the poor Uſurer
Trembled as Bauds beneath the laſh.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: He comes then.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: With as much joy, as to receive a hanging.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.p: He would be whipt, and ſay his prayers at Pauls in a white ſheet.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: That were penance to him:
Nay he would pay as much as he ſhould fine
For Alderman, though half his ſoul went with it,
For his Quictus; he does apprehend
Nothing but earthquakes.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: How I am rampant
With the imagination? bid the muſick
Be ready, they know all their flouriſhes:
But ſhift you quickly—My honourable Lords.—
How they do look like States-men! where's your tooth-pick?
Excellent! beat your ſtaff hanſomly; contract
Your brow, and look more ſuperciliouſly.

sp.speaker: 1 Lord.
sp.l: I warrant you for my part.

sp.speaker: 2 Lord.
sp.l: We came now from practice.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Can ye do't with confidence?

sp.speaker: 2 Lord.
sp.l: Theſe very cloathes have made me proud already:
It was ſome Lords caſt ſute, I'll lay my life.

sp.speaker: 3 Lord.
sp.l: And mine; it ſmells of honour.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: More perfume, ſo, ſo; how now man?

sp.speaker: 2 Lord.
sp.l: He looks pale; my Lord, how d'ye?

sp.speaker: 3 Lord.
sp.l: Well, well, I hope 'tis but conceipt.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: 3 Lord.
sp.l: Will the pox lie in cloathes? I cannot tell,
I finde ſome alteration in my body
Since I ſhifted.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: 'Tis a meer conceipt;
They were an honeſt mans, upon my knowledge,
A Captain of the Train'd-Band in the Country:
They were bought againſt the general muſter laſt;
He wore 'em that day, and moſt carefully ſent 'em up
To taſt our London lavender.

sp.speaker: 3 Lord.
sp.l: Sir, you have
Satisfied me.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Be ſprighful: where's this Prince,
Whoſe nod muſt make us double before age?
I long to kiſs his hand.

sp.speaker: 2 Lord.
sp.l: He's here.

div.stage: Enter Lambert, Playfaire's brother, for the fourth Lord, Sir Poldavis and attendants.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Now by that ſprig, a pretty lump of Majeſty,
No actor could become it half ſo royally:
But wilt thou not be out of thy Kings part,
And when wine is wanting at the banquet,
Call upon drawers, quarrel with your Nobles?
Or when we ſhall preſent our man of morgages,
Take him aſide, and borrow half a crown
To give your whore benevolence, which truſted
For you laſt tilting; or be drunk too ſoon,
And leave our project in the durt?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: My Lords,
This fellow's inſolence muſt be corrected:
Diſpoſe him in what priſon you think fit.

sp.speaker: 4 Lord.
sp.l: He's mad, I think.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: To Bedlam with him then:
Is this a place for fools and madmen? who
Admitted him? take him away; ſee you
He be well whipt, and let him thank our mercy,
Bandog.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: I quake already; excellent Lambert!
Cool, cool thy lungs, and whiſper with ſome Lord,
Thou wo't be a key too high elſe: good ſir Poldavis,
Maſter of the houſe, at whoſe coſt we are
Entertained!

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: My part is rotten
In my head, doubt not.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Is he come?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: He waits at the firſt chamber.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Then let the Lutes
Begin, and then admit him.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Here's revelling, my purſe muſt be ſqueez'd for't:
That's the King, the reſt are bare; how ſupple they are
I'th' hams? that Courtier has oyled his joynts:
He looks this way, they point at me; a rot
O'that knaves finger.

sp.speaker: 2 Lord.
sp.l: What fellow's this? who waits?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: It was his Graces pleaſure he was ſent for.

sp.speaker: 2 Lord.
sp.l: My good Lord.

sp.speaker: 4 Lord.
sp.l: My Lord of Noland, as you were ſaying.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Is this the man whom you ſo much commended for his abilities?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I ſmell no good from that word ability.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Diſcreet, and read i'th' Common-wealth, a man
Fit for employment in ſome Embaſſie?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: The very ſame.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: His countenance is promiſing.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: If the King
Of Spain had but his head, that politick head,
I know who might go fiſh for the Low-Countries.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: His garments are but courſe.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: His mind is rich.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: They praiſe me: I am a thouſand pounds the worſe.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Kneel down, thy name?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Gyles Hornet, your poor creature.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: We'll knight him.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I do beſeech you, ſir, to ſpare this honour,
I am not able to maintain my ſelf;
There be more Knights then can live well already.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Neglect his favour?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Be it your care
To give his body more becoming ornaments,
He ſhall be like himſelf then; we will confer
More honours on him.

sp.speaker: 4 Lord
sp.l: Do you make haſte, his Grace
Will have you new thatch'd; you muſt have rich cloaths
Fitting your ſtate and honourable title.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Theſe will be good enough for me, 'las I am not able.

sp.speaker: 4 Lord.
sp.l: Nay you muſt have them from his Wardrobe, ſir,
They'll coſt you nothing; you'll not look in theſe
Like a poor Knight of Windſore.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Where be the Ladies, and the Bride?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: She's your Graces handmaid; they
Are dancing, ſir, within.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Direct us to 'em prethee;
VVhen he is ready give us knowledge—

sp.speaker: 4 Lord.
sp.l: Yes, ſir.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: VVhat will become of me?

sp.speaker: 4 Lord.
sp.l: You were beſt prepare,
Your cloaths will be here preſently; the King
VVill ſend to you before y'are ready; caſt
Your old skin off: do you not to ſave ſheets
And trouble, wrap your ſelf anights i'th' blankets?
Chare they aſham'd to ſhew the linings?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Hum; if this be but a preparative for a whipping,
VVhat caſe am I in?

sp.speaker: 4 Lord.
sp.l: VVell ſaid, now they are come,
Be nimble now, and help to ſtrip him.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: 'Las, muſt I wear this doublet? it would yeild
Heaven knows how much to burn.

sp.speaker: 4 Lord.
sp.l: You may be deſperate
VVhen 'tis on, and burn your body with it, ſir.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I ſha'not know my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Fit as 'twere made, ſir.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Which is ſir Gyles?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I am not Knighted yet.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: You have your grace, and may be call'd ſo.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Have I the grace to be a Knight?
I am the man you pleaſe to call ſir Gyles.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Then I congratulate your happy fortune;
Y'are like to be exalted; his Grace talks
Much on you; I'll be proud to be your ſervant:
Sir Robert, a word.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: VVhat gentleman is this?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: The Bridegroom, ſir; in great favour I can tell you,
And new created by his Highneſs, Baron
Of Landskip; his living is far off.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: My very good Lord, my breeches are almoſt on.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Here be your keys.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: His Majeſty has pleas'd to ſhine upon
A piece of barren earth.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: You are too modeſt:
The King hath been informed, ſir Gyles, you are
One of the ableſt men in his Dominions:
Should vertue ſtill be cloath'd in rags? advance it
To honour and regard: you waſte your brain
At home in cheap and low engagements, ſweat
Your ſoul out, for a poor and paltry living:
Old houſes, let 'em fall to the dull Lord
O'th' Manner; ſwitch me up a town together,
Or meddle not; this and that ſtrading Acre
Not worth your care: ſtudy ſome Monopoly,
May ſweep the Kingdom at a ſtroak: deſpiſe
A project will not bring in half the City:
Find out a way to forfeit all the Charters:
Have an exchequer of your own, and keep
The Princes round about in penſion:
Theſe are becoming buſineſſes, and ſpeak a States-man.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: You do talk ſtrange things, my Lord:
So, now my keys, good gentlemen, my keys.

sp.speaker: 4 Lord.
sp.l: You have 'em, ſir.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Cry mercy.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: They are things
Material to our buſineſs.

sp.speaker: 4 Lord.
sp.l: And we'll have 'em again:
Let me alone, the Barbour has not done yet;
When he's i'th' ſuds, we may be more familiar
With's worſhips pocket, and return 'em quaintly.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: I will account it one of my felicities
To be a witneſs of your honour, ſir.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Oh my good Lord of Landskip.—

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: How ſhall we diſpoſe of theſe?

sp.speaker: 4 Lord.
sp.l: The Hangman will not have 'em; and I fear
They will corrupt the well; faith give 'em ſtable-room,
The are dung already.—

sp.speaker: 1 Lord.
sp.l: My Lord, the King asks for you; good ſir Gyles, 'tis
ſo decreed; write me i'th' number of your faithful friends.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: We muſt attend.

sp.speaker: 4 Lord.
sp.l: Do not yet ſay he's ready,
The Barber has a duty to diſpatch,
He will be an hour a rubbing, waſhing, powdering:
Then I'll attend him to his preſence.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: We ſhall excuſe him ſo long, ſtill your ſervant—

sp.speaker: 4 Lord.
sp.l: The Barber, ſir, attends in the next room.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I wo'not ſhave.

sp.speaker: 4 Lord.
sp.l: He fears his throat.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I never
Give above three pence.

sp.speaker: 4 Lord.
sp.l: Talk not you of charge,
You have but yet your welcome; do not you
Think, good ſir Gyles, but we can ſhave you too.—

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Where is he, Cloſe?

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: I told him, ſir,
You lay in a chamber o'the t'other ſide
The houſe, whither he's gone with his ſword drawn,
And curſes of themſelves able to kill you;
You did affront him once, and now his Miſtreſs
Has quite neglected him, for your love, he thinks;
He'll make you an example to all rivals;
I'll bring your cloaths t'ye after: yet your fear
And running, ſir, will keep you warm enough.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Honeſt Cloſe, thou haſt ſav'd my life.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: Death, is he not behind you? this way, good ſir.—

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: Have you not made a fine choice? I did ever
Think he was falſe; your mother did but counterfeit
The love-ſick widow, all this while, to try him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: To try him, Nurſe?

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: She told me ſo her ſelf,
Aſſuring him the ſtate was hers, and you
At her devotion: put him to his choice
To take her with the wealth, or you with nothing;
What followed you have heard: come, be wiſe yet,
And love the Country-Gentleman, that dotes on you;
He's rich and half a fool: I'll fetch him to you.—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: My mother counterfeit? why may not Hartwel
Pretend as well as ſhe, fearing her anger
And policy, if he refus'd her love?
I have obſerv'd ſome ſorrow in his geſture,
As he were willing to deliver ſomething,
If opportunity would give him leave:
He cannot be ſo falſe; now I ſuſpect
He does obey ſome dire neceſſity;
Twould puzzle a wiſe lover to be ſo
Severely put to't.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: On like a bold Captain,
Give her a broad ſide, ſhe's within your ſhot;
I'll leave you.—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'Tis the fool; why Nurſe?

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Nay, flee not,
Before you hear.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: 'Tis Hartwel.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: If my voice
Betray me not.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Why in this ſhape? ſome trick in't,
He hides his face; I'll put him to't however,
Although the hour be unſeaſonable; any time
We may expreſs our joy: my Nurſe once told me
You were not well, and gone to bed: your health
Is welcome as mine own; I dare not, ſir,
In modeſty preſume to bid you ſtay,
And to requite your pains, kind Maſter Startup.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: She knows me not.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Forgive me if I bluſh:
I have no other way, but to declare
My eyes that late frown'd on your love, ſhall ſmile.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: On me?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: On none but you: I have been too
Unkindly dealt withal by Hartwel, whom
How dearly I affected, good heavens knows:
But I have read diſcretion to my fancie,
And were he here, he ſhould be witneſs of
My vows to you, if you accept my heart,
And can with equal truth embrace it: I
Will chuſe my husband here; you, only you:
This Faith is regiſtred in heaven, ſhall challenge
From me a wives obedience.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: Away, her mother's up; I would not for
A thouſand pound ſhe finde you in this chamber.—

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: I have undone my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: Sweet Maſter Startup
To your own lodging, take this cloſe lanthorn with ye.
Paſſion of me, what makes her riſe?

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: I will diſcover yet.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: Diſcover what?
How! Maſter Hartwel!

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: You have midnight-plots.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: Oh we are wretched miſerable! what have I done?—

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Oh who ſhall lead me to a world where are
No women! farewell all: I'll be above
Your charms, and finde out death a cure for love.—

div.head: Actus Quartus.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: WHere are we now? 'tis very cold, why doſt not
Lead to ſome houſe?

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: What at this time of night?
All people are abed; the very Owls
Are in their dead ſleep: or if we could
Be admitted, would you venture a this faſhion,
And publiſh your diſgrace? proclaim your ſelf
Coward, and lay ſome imputation
Upon the place you came from, where your hopes
May yet be fair for marriage? this brunt over,
To meet a drunkard now were comfortable,
Whoſe eyes inflam'd would ſerve inſtead of torches,
Or he might ſpit Flap-Dragons from his fire
Of Sack, and light us; but no ſober man
Conſidering what caſe you are in, ſir,
By my conſent ſhould ſee us.—

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Ha, what's that?

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: Where? where? a fire-Drake?

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Now 'tis gone, 'tis bright
Again, is't not a ſpirit? Oh deliver me!

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: I have heard ſome ſuch things uſe to walk the Fields.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: What ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: Pray, pray, with as much ſtrength
As if you had no land, or were confin'd
To my Annuity; now I hear no ſpirits,
This riches makes us cowards: hide your ſelf,
I will go nearer.—

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Doſt know the devil if thou ſeeſt him, Cloſe?
A pox a love, if this be the reward on't;
Some call it fire, but I find no ſuch matter;
I am frozen to the blanket, and my teeth
Strike one another, and keep time like hammers;
I do believe if they were beaten out,
They would make falſe Dice, there's Quick-ſilver in 'em
Already by their dancing.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: Sir, where are you?

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Here I am, here ſtill.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: Y'are a dead man.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: More terrour? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: 'Tis my Maſter
With a dark lanthorn, and purſues us, by
This darkneſs; 'tis his voice, wrap your ſelf up,
And roul into ſome ditch; flight will betray us.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: I were as good be kil'd, and yet I'll venter.—

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: 'Tis he indeed, and more then I expected:
The matters do not fadge well with his Miſtreſs.

div.stage: Enter Hartwel with a dark lanthorn.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: What a ſweet thing is night! how calm and harmleſs!
No whiſpering but of leaves, on which the breath
Of heaven plays muſick, to the birds that ſlumber:
Here are no objects to betray our ſence
To a repentance; nor can women thus
Advantag'd by the tapers of the night,
Spread their temptations to undo poor man:
What a fine book is heaven! which we may read
Beſt now when every ſtar is a fair letter:
How much they wrong thee, night, that call thee guilty
Of rapes and murders? 'tis the day that like
A glorious whore ingageth men to act 'em;
And taking then the darkneſs to obſcure 'em,
We unjuſtly lay the ſhame upon thy brows
That art ſo innocent, thou never ſawſt 'em:
Befriended with the ſilence I begin
To wander; there's no wilderneſs abroad
To him, that's loſt at home.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: One that has ta'en ſome pains for you to night:
I am Cloſe.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: VVhat mak'ſt thou here?

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: I wait upon my charge,
I lead your Rival a proceſſion
In's ſhirt, perſwading him you had reſolv'd
To cut his throat elſe: he's hard by at's prayers,
And thinks you have purſu'd him.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Ha! I'll do't:
Shew me the fool, by all my hopes I'll kill him,
And ſend his baſe heart, as a preſent to her:
Fate has preſented me with this revenge,
And I will not delay his death a minute.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: Indeed, indeed you ſha'not.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: You dare not.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: My drudge offront me? are you grown his champion?

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: Not I, ſir, but you dare not do an act
So much againſt the honour of a gentleman;
You wo'not kill him baſely.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: VVhy then
There is no fear, but he'll live long enough:
I'll undertake, he ne'er ſhall grow provided
To fight with ye; and other ſatisfaction,
Name it and take it; ſo I'll fetch him to you.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Stay, I have been too paſſionate, let him live
To be her puniſhment; that's revenge enough
While I purſue my own ways.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: VVhither now?

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: VVhither you muſt not follow, by thy honeſty:
I charge thee come not after me.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: That binds my attendance, ſir.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: But not when I command the contrary:
If thou doſt move this way, thou draw'ſt mine anger:
Mind the preſervation of the ſame thing you
Undertook: farewel; if thou doſt love me,
Follow not, nor queſtion; 'tis in my power
To looſe thee or my ſelf.—

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: I cannot ſee i'th' dark with ſpectacles,
And mine eyes have loſt him o'the ſudden;
VVell, I muſt hope the beſt: what ſhall I do
VVith my hen-hearted lover, who would give
Half his eſtate, this cold fit were well over?
I ſhall make work for the Phyſitians:
Caudles and Cullices will not reſtore him;
If he but ſcape with life, I am not ſorry:
He may be a ſouldier, and endure the trenches;
I put him firſt to the becoming ſufferance.
But what are theſe? an army of horns and halberts?
Upon my conſcience the VVatch: I thought
The Fields had not been haunted with theſe goblins:
I cannot run; if I ſhould ſquat, and they
Find me, there were no mercy but Bridewel,
Or ſome ſuch louſie place: I am reſolv'd
To caſt away a few good words upon 'em;
A leg, and worſhipping the Conſtable
That leads the ruſty regiment, will quit me;
I paſs the gates with't often, and ſo may
The devil, if he pay the Porter. Bleſs ye
My Maſters, what a clock is't?

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.l: VVho goes there?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: I charge you ſtand.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: Your worſhip may do much.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: VVhere have you been?

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: At Iſtington, an't pleaſe you, about buſineſs.

sp.speaker: 2 Watch.
sp.l: Some thief I warrant him, no honeſt man,
I know by his basket-hilt; ſome rogue that watches:
The Fields are peſter'd with ſuch ſturdy robbers.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: He is a rogue that watches, for my part.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: He calls my VVatch-men rogues, perfidious traytor.

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.l: How! Maſter Conſtable,
You are one your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Sitrah I will teach you to commit felony.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.p: How, ſir? will you teach me to commit felony? take heed what you ſay, if I commit fellony by your authority.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: My tority ſhall ſtretch for't: away with him; if you be not whipt for theſe intergatories, his Majeſty ſhall keep his own peace himſelf; is this a time anight to call honeſt men rogues? away with him.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: Good fir.

sp.speaker: 2 Watch.
sp.l: We will provide you lodging.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: 2 Watch.
sp.l: New priſon.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: But are you in earneſt, gentlemen? for what?

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.l: For anſwering the Conſtable.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: Cry him mercy,
I ſhew'd him too much manners, if there be
No remedy.

sp.speaker: 2 Watch.
sp.l: We'll humble you.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: I have a
Companion hereabouts: where are you, ſir?

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Star. Here in a ditch.

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.l: They ſeldom go alone,
We'll find him out. Ha ſirrah?

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: Do you hear,
You watch about theſe places for no good,
It ſeems.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: We watch indeed for knaves.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: You dare not
Speak to their faces: ſome of you I am ſure
Do watch for your good Maſters o'th' Pariſh.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: I thank you honeſt men; where art thou, Cloſe?

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: Here: theſe good men will help us to a lodging.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Bleſſing a'their heart; I am almoſt ſtarv'd.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Yes, yes, we'll d'ye that favour: come away, ſir.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Where ſhall we go now?

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.l: To priſon.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: How, Cloſe?

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: You ſhall be cloſe enough.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: I follow, ſir,
I cannot leave you in adverſity:
All this is for your health: clean ſtraw is warm, ſir.
You have the benefit of being naked;
I ſhall have work to morrow in my woollen.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Away, away, bring 'em away.—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I heard ſome noiſe, look, call up the ſervants,
See if the gentlemen beabed; I'm troubled
I have not dealt ſo nobly as became me
With Hartwel; and that love which I pretended,
If I have drawn his fancy to affect me,
Muſt make him ſatisfaction; his language
And ſoft demeanor, when he gave me up
His reſolution, made me quite forget
My purpoſe to have chid him for his levity,
So ſoon to leave my daughter, who I know
Hath plac'd him neer her heart; and I have done
Her injurie, by this tryal of her truth.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: Oh Miſtreſs!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: Maſter Startup
Is not abed, nor Maſter Hartwel.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: This is very ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: I dare not tell her of his ſhift, they're gone,
The doors I found left open, and no ſigne
Which way they are beſtowed.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: This puzzles me:
Pray heaven there be no miſchief in this abſence:
Is Franck abed?

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: What ſhould
Move 'em to leave my houſe ſo late? and Maſter Hartwel
Without his cloaths? ſome knock; they're there; go ſee.—
Beſhrow me but I trembled.

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: 'Tis a ſtranger,
And ſays he would ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: At this late hour?
What accidents are theſe? from whence?

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Has he no name? what ſhould this mean?

sp.speaker: Nurſe.
sp.l: He ſays,
He is a Country-man of Maſter Startups.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Admit him, he perhaps may bring ſome newes.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.l: By your leave Miſtreſs, pardon my importunity
At ſo unfit an hour.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Y'are welcome, ſir.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.l: I met with fortunate directions,
Though I came late: I underſtand you have
A gueſt, one Startup, of Northamptonſhire,
That comes a woing to your daughter.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Such
A one there was that ſupt with us, and went
To bed; but ſince, as I have faith, I know not
Which way he has convey'd himſelf: another
Gentleman too is miſſing, and his rival.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.l: Pray do not mock me, Lady; I have rid
A great way, and the buſineſs much concerns him.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You may believe me: he is no ſuch treaſure,
I ſhould conceal him

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.l: Then I ſee you dally;
Know, Miſtreſs, you may ſlack your preparations,
Your daughter muſt look out another husband;
He is contracted.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.l: And ſomething more,
Gotten with childe one that without bluſhing
I cannot call my daughter; he ſhall make
Her credit ſtreight again: although my fortunes
Have no equality with his, I ſhall
Finde law to force him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You prefer'd this ſutor:
This news returns my blood.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Sir, you ſhall finde
All truth I have delivered; I am not ſorry
To hear this news; this is no time to ſeek him:
Plcaſe you accept the lodging that was his:
My ſervant ſhall attend you in the morning,
To help you ſearch.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.l: You ſeem a noble gentlewoman,
I take your courteſie.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Nurſe, a light: pray walk, ſir.—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I was unkind to Hartwel, he not wiſe:
But love ſtill apprehends too much or nothing.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Frances, a word: do you not know what is
Become o'theſe Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Not I, their abſence is ſtrange to me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Oh Franck, I am undone.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Good heaven forbid.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: This Gentleman, Maſter Hartwel,
Whom we ſhall never ſee again, I fear.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: How, mother! are you acquainted with any cauſe to
fear thus?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: 'Tis in vain to tell thee how I lov'd him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Bleſs my ſences! you love him?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: 'Bove all the world, affectionately plac'd him
Too neer my heart.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I heard you made pretence
Of love, to try him for my ſake; and pardone me
If yet I dare not believe more.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Oh Franck!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: My heart doth tremble, I feel coldneſs run
Through all my veins.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I had no other thought
At firſt, but wiſely to diſtinguiſh whether
His heart was fixt on thee, or my eſtate;
With reſolution, if I found him more
A courtier of thy fortune, then thy perſon,
To puniſh him with loſs of both: but love
Hath chang'd the ſcoene and title of our Comedy;
And what I meant ſhould ſlip—All his hopes,
Hath ruin'd us: his modeſt and calm anſwer,
To accept my tender, with ſuch force and reaſon
Directed to my fancie, turn'd my purpoſe,
And made me his indeed, his perfect lover:
But now we have both loſt him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: All the piety
That ever taught children to love their mother,
Will but ſuffice to keep my heart obedient:
Was ever maid ſo miſerable? was there
No other in my fate to be my rival?
I live too long. Oh break, my poor heart, break;
Then ſhe that gave me life, hath took it from me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Why do you weep?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I do not weep; or if
I do, I know not why.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Now I perceive,
Thy duty was but counterfeit; you love him,
Upon my life you love him ſtill: have my
Commands no more reſpect? my care and love
So ill rewarded? that I deſiring
One comfort in the world, and ſhall my childe
Riſe up to take that from me?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Alas, I knew not
You lov'd him too; indeed I had rather die
Then you ſhould call me rebel: parents often
Affect not where their children love; but you
With too much loving what my thoughts delight in,
Have quite undone your daughter.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Now I ſee
The cauſe of his departure in this faſhion:
Pray heaven he have not made away himſelf:
Did ever childe deceive a mother ſo?
I have a ſad preſage: you may to bed,
And riſe again without my bleſſing; yet
You may ſtay—Wherefore ſhould I deſpair
Of his return? you ſay you could not tell
That I affected him.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Indeed not I,
And do believe it now againſt my will;
But I am your daughter.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Shewing it in conforming
Your ſelf to my deſires, and what is paſt
I can forgive you: if he come again,
Will you be rul'd, and ſhew no favour to him?
For 'tis in you I ſee to make me happy:
I will not tye you to affect th'other:
Chuſe any for your husband, but this man,
My love and prayers ſhall go along with you.
Anſwer.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Indeed I dare not, yet could I
Put off the knowledge that you are my mother.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Though my imagination allow'd you
The greateſt Empreſs in the world, whoſe frown
Could kill, and eyes at pleaſure make alive
Again, thus I could anſwer.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: pray let's hear?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: You do not well to heap oppreſſion:
Authority was given to preſerve,
Not kill the poor beneath you: I durſt tell you
In confidence of my cauſe, that you betray
Two innocents to ſorrow; and though heaven
Look on, and ſeem to ſmile upon your cruelty,
Yet there is thunder, for divorcing thoſe,
Whoſe hearts That hath conjoyn'd: I durſt fay more,
Though all your terrors were prepar'd to puniſh
My bold defence, and call you tyrant.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Fran
sp.l: A moſt unjuſt, a ſacrilegious tyrant.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You would not be ſo violent.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: That do
Not onely ruine and deface the altar,
But ſteal away the very ſacrifice:
And I durſt adde, and ſmile upon your anger,
Though as you frown'd, death lurk'd in every wrinkle,
My ſoul's above your tyranny; and would
From torturing flames receive new fire of love,
And make your eye faint to behold the brightneſs
Of my poor bodies Martyrdome; and if ever
Love ſhew'd a miracle, my heart ſhould bear
The characters of him you have torn from it,
With beams about it like a Saint that ſuffer'd.
But as you are my mother, thus I kneel,
And beg a pardon for my innocence;
If that offend you, live you happy ſtill,
And be the Miſtreſs of your vows: live to
Enjoy whom you affect; may every hour
Return new bleſſings on you both; renew
Your ſpring, and let him think you young again;
And let me beg but this for all my duty,
Againſt the day you marry him, to provide
My coffin; for I fear, I ſha'not have
Breath many minutes after, to pray for you:
The herbs that ſhall adorn your bridal chamber,
Will ſerve my funeral, and deck my hearſe:
Beneath which you ſhall ſay, There lies your daughter
That dy'd to ſhew obedience.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Why ſhouldſt thou
Continue thus to him?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I know he loves me
Still, though hereafter your affections
May meet.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: And they ſhall meet,
But never to procure thee one bad thought:
Now I have tryed you both, aſſure my child
I lov'd him but for thee; diſpoſe thy ſelf
