To be his bride; this news at his return
VVill make all well: —To reſt.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Can this be true?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: 'Twere ſin to mock thee any more—To bed.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: No, I'll ſpend all this night in prayers for you,
My deareſt mother: Oh my Hartwel!—

div.stage: Enter Playfaire, and the Doctor his Brother.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: How like you her now?

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: The morning never bloom'd
So freſh, nor Venus with more charms upon her:
Adon would melt before her eye, and woo
Her kiſſes at the expence of her laſt breath:
Cupid himſelf, could he but ſee, would fall
In love with her, and throwing away his ſhafts,
Offer the empty quiver to her eyes,
Ambitious to fill it with her beams,
The leaſt of which would wound more hearts, then all
His ſtock of golden arrows.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: No more raptures.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Didſt thou not know before, that love is able
VVithout the help of ſack to make a poet?
My nimble Mercury; Joves Herald in
Reverſion.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: I confeſs,
I had a trick of Mercury, when I pick'd
His pocket for the keys.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: He never miſt 'em.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: His eyes were drench'd in ſuds, and we return'd 'em
Ere they recover'd light.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: 'Twas excellent,
He was in darkneſs ſtill.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: D'ye think he'll know her?

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: His cloaths already have.
Made him forget himſelf; or if he have
But the remembrance of ſuch a woman,
The more he ſees her now, the more he'll think
The change impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: VVhere have you left him?

sp.speaker: Play
sp.l: I'th' Gallery, where with much patience,
He does expect his Highneſs will ſend for him.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Then all runs ſmooth, his wonder does continue.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: I fed that humour artificially,
He is half perſwaded all is but a dream yet:
To which imagination, his cloaths
Are a great help, becauſe he paid not for 'em:
Sometimes he is very merry, then again
He ſtruts about with ſuch a ſcurvie pride,
As ſome new crept into nobility,
VVhen ſome of their firſt livery come to ſee 'em.
His honour has ſo chang'd him, that he now
Knows not of what religion he is;
Or if by chance he thinks of his firſt faith,
He ſpits o'th' hangings, and excuſes with
I do not like the ſtory, 'tis apocryphal:
Sometimes he'll offer at a jeſt,
Frown upon any man that will preſume
To have more knowledge in worſe cloaths: I told him
It was his Graces pleaſure he ſhould be
Controuler at the Mask, and he did ſweat
As he were ſtudying for ſome mighty oaths
To cleat the preſence.—He is here, away—

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Are you the Maſter of the houſe, ſir Poldavis?
I heard you call'd.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: It is my name,
Sir Gyles, unworthy of this Grace his Highneſs
Is daign'd to ſhew in honouring of my daughter.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And was ſhe married this morning, ſay you?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: This morn ſhe loſt her Virgin-Name.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I have
Not ſeen her yet, nor any of the Ladies;
You have but little noiſe methinks i'th' houſe.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: It would offend his Grace.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: VVho as you ſay
Came hither privately, with a ſmall train
Of Lords: would I might ſee his face again:
I am not ſent for yet; I have been ready,
Sir Pol—theſe three hours; and I do wonder
His Grace ſo much for gets himſelf.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: That muſick
Speaks him on entrance.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I, this garb becomes him;
How was his perſon loſt within that ſhape
He was firſt preſented to me!

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Indeed the caſe
Is ſomething altered, by your Highneſs bounty,
To your poor ſervant Hornet.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: How he looks
As he did ſcorn the Quorum, and were hungry
To eat a States-man! 'las an office in
The houſhold is too little for a breakfaſt,
A Baron but a mornings draught, he'll gulp it
Like a round egge in Muſcadine; methinks
At every wiping of his mouth, ſhould drop
Agolden ſaying of Pythagoras:
A piece of Matchiavel ſee already
Hang on his beard, which wants but ſtroking out;
The ſtatutes and the Magna Charta have
Taken a Leaſe at his tongues end.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: We'll think on't; he ſhall be—But
To the banquet: Then let the Mask be ready,
There we ſhall employ your worthy diligence.—

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Heaven bleſs your mighty Grace.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: You'll follow.—

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I attend you preſently:
I know not what to think of theſe things yet;
'Tis very ſtrange I ſhould be thus exalted,
Without deſert, beſt known unto my ſelf:
Princes I ſee are mortal, and may be
Deceived in placing of their honours: I
Am little better then a favorite,
If theſe be true, if theſe be true; 'tis a queſtion,
Let me conſider wiſely; it may be
I am not I, not Hornet, no, I'm a Knight:
Are theſe my cloaths? I do not uſe to wear ſuch:
A pocket in my ſleeve, and velvet hoſe,
Six times tranſlated ſince they were a Midwifes
Forepart, were things I wore on holydays:
The price of theſe would break a Camels back;
And yet ſome men walk under them like Elephants,
And have variety as the devil were
Their Taylour; who beſt knows where all their land lies:
Then why this coſt on me?—'Tis a dream;
I am now confirm'd, a very idle dream,
And I am very glad on't: 'tis impoſſible
It ſhould be true, it does not hang together:
I will have paience, till I wake again,
And care not what becomes on't.

div.stage: Enter Playfaires brother for the 4 Lord.

sp.speaker: 4 Lord.
sp.l: 'Tis his highneſs pleaſure,
Now the banquet's done.—

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: How, the banquet done! I was coming to't'
You could hardly ſay grace by this time.

sp.speaker: 4 Lord.
sp.l: That's a ceremony
Grown out of uſe; it was a running banquet.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: A running! ſo it ſeems, it was a galloping banquet,
For you made haſte: I do dream certainly,
There's no ſence nor reaſon in any thing they do.

sp.speaker: 4 Lord.
sp.l: You know your place,
The Mask will ſtreight begin; and his Grace will not
Have any one admitted: he reſolves,
If the conceipt affects him, it ſhall be
Perform'd at Court hereafter: i'th' mean time
He does command all privacie; they are
Some ſet to guard the door, but your care muſt
Provide his Highneſs be not interrupted:
Hark, they are rude already—

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Let me alone:
What turbulent knave is that?

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: I am a Country-Gentleman, ſir Gyles;
And if I may preſume upon good cloaths,
You may before his Grace call me your Cozen,
And not be aſham'd: here is a Lady too.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: A Lady too? is ſhe with child? what makes ſhe
Here, and ſhe be with child already? I
Tell thee, none ſuch ſhall be admitted while
I am in place—More rapping?—Keep the doors,
If I do fall a ſwearing once, look to't.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: I beſeech you for my wives ſake.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Thy wives?
What's he that pleads in forma pauperis?

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: A Citizen, and like me.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Like me? thou lieſt, I am more like a Lord,
Thou ſha't fare ne'er the better for that word:
Knock down the women, if there be a hundred,
And make their husbands drunk, the guard are lazie:
Theſe womens inſolence will force a ſtatute:
I will petition to the Prince my ſelf,
They may have liberty but once a year
To ſee the galliefoyſt, then be confin'd
To their chamber and one 'Prentiſe— Yet again?

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Sir Gyles, ſir Gyles, you know me well enough.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: But while I am in office, I know no body.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: I am your Scrivener.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Draw the purſe wherein
Thou keptſt thy ears, and leave 'em at the door,
The guard truſts none without a pawn; they'll ſerve
If they be ne'er redeem'd, to ſeeth in milk
For a ſore throat.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Sir Gyles, here is your Neece.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: My Neece! the devil ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: VVithin. Pray Unckle let me in.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Her very voice—Ha, open the doors there:
Where is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Whom?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: My Neece that call'd me?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: None call'd, nor was there any women here.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: No, nor my Scrivener, bawling out ſir Gyles?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Not any nam'd your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Then I dream,
And I am a fool to make a queſtion on't.—

sp.speaker: VVithin.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: The Knaves laugh at me too; but let 'em: I
Shall be as merry with this tale to morrow.
What fancies men have in their ſleep ſometimes!
His Highneſs! where be the Ladies?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: They are all i'th' Mask.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Nay, no matter where; why do I ask the queſtion?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: You'll ſee them, ſir, anon.
sp.stage: Poldavis gives papers to Lambert and ſir Gyles.
sp.l: Wilt pleaſe your Grace,
And you, ſir Gyles, the ſubject of the Mask?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: What's here? The three Goddeſſes Contention for the Golden Ball.

div.stage: Enter Playfaire in his own apparel: He dances with a golden Ball in his hand.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: This is Paris, ha! I have ſeen that face before now.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Theſe are the three Goddeſſes.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Juno, Pallas and Venus.

div.stage: The Goddeſſes dance, and court Paris for his Ball: To Juno enters one like a King; She takes off his Crown, and offereth it to Paris: he accepts not.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Juno doth woo him with her State and Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: But he refuſes.

div.stage: To Pallas enters one like a Souldier, plum'd and rich: She preſents him to Paris, with a book; he refuſes.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: He is not for her ſervice, though ſhe offer
To make him Scholar and a Souldier,
A compleat man.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: That Fairy wins the Ball.

div.stage: To Venus comes Cupid, leading in Hornets Neece, riehly dreſt.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Ha! that is my Neece.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Which, ſir Gyles?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: That Lady whom Dame Venus and her brat are buſie
withal.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Contain your ſelf, ſir Gyles, that is the Bride.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: The Bride quotha!

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Married this morning.

div.stage: Paris gives Venus the Ball: Juno, Pallas, King and Souldier.—

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Theſe are my keys; ſhe's ſafe enough at home,
And has but half her wits, as I remember:
The devil cannot juggle her from my cuſtody: Ha, ha,
I do dream ſtill.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: 'Tis time to break off ſports: how like you this,
Sir Gyles?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: A very pretty dream.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I ſee you wo'd be abed, you are not us'd to ſuch late
hours.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Lights for his Highneſs.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I humbly beg your licence,
I may return to my old lodging.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Well ſir, 'tis eaſily granted.—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Lights for ſir Gyles, one ſhall attend you home.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Why do you laugh?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: At a conceipt, at a conceipt:
What did I eat laſt night, to make me dream thus?—

div.head: Actus Quintus.
div.stage: Enter Hartwel, Country-Gentleman, Servant and Officers.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: YOu have done well.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.l: VVould you had done no worſe:
Theſe are his cloaths, and you muſt give account
How you came by 'em, and produce him ſafe,
Ere you acquit your ſelf: we may ſuſpect
You have kill'd him.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Then I obey my deſtiny:
Juſtice will ſtill purſue the guilty perſon;
Diſpoſe me where you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: He does confeſs.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: What ere you be, you can but have my life
For his; all your revenge can reach no higher,
And to the law I yeild my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.l: My hopes are
Cold as his blood whom thou haſt ſlain: thou haſt
Been cruel in this act, to me and mine,
VVhoſe fames in him are miſerably wounded;
But look for the reward.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: I muſt expect it:
In the mean time, I wo'not beg your mercy;
Life is a burden I would fain be rid of,
Does weary me to carry it.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I'll acquaint
My Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.l: Do ſo: to the next juſtice with him,
Come away.—

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: She's gone; ſhe's gone, I ſhall run mad: my Neece,
Rob'd of three thouſand pounds in her eſcape,
And yet the doors were ſafe: ſome witch has taught her,
Or ſome French boy, to clime a chimney; elſe
I cannot think which way ſhe is convey'd:
I find too late, I am awake and gul'd,
Nor know I whom to accuſe for my tormentors,
Devils or men; but ſure they were not men,
But very fiends I revell'd with laſt night:
Though mortals want no malice, they have not art
To undo me of this faſhion: Oh that I
Knew where to meet the prince of devils knighted me;
The Poets call him Pluto, god of riches;
I and my learned counſel would undo him
In law, in very law, which he ſhould find
Hotter ere I had done, then hell it ſelf,
And call his place of torments in three terms,
But a refreſhing to't: yet let me ſee,
I have her portion ſtill, though ſhe be vaniſht;
That's better then my Neece; but if ſhe marry,
I looſe it all; there, there is the vexation.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Save Maſter Hornet.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: 'Tis too late, away,
I do not love unneceſſary complement.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: This he?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Yes I am he, am I not very fine?
What do you think this trim will coſt me? ha!
Three thouſand pound, no more.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: The broker wo'not
Lend half the mony.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Will you, ſir, be gone?
I have no money to lend now; it is not
You know in faſhion, with rich cloaths.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I am
For other purpoſe, and with news perhaps
You would be willing to receive; you have
A Neece.—

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: No, ſuch a creature was in my poſſeſſion:
Do you know where ſhe is?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I imagine.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Ha! good Maſter Lambert, on, pray forward;
You ſhall have mony upon good ſecurity.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I thank you ſir, for nothing; I owe you
Too much already, on theſe terms.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: My Neece,
As you were ſaying.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Were you knighted lately?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Ha! is that talk abroad?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: No general rumour; by a chance I came
Where ſuch a thing was whiſper'd, only whiſper'd,
Juſt as he was deſcrib'd: in my opinion
Y'are very hanſome, and do look as like.—

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: An aſs.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: VVhy you ſhall have it, ſir.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: But touching
My Neece, good ſir, that moſt ungratious giglot,
That's run or ſtolen away, juggled laſt night
Out of my doors.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Did ſhe not leap the Caſement?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Do not encreaſe my agonie, you came.—

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: With civil meaning to diſcover how
You may be abus'd.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: VVhat mony do you want, ſir?
Your own bond ſhall ſuffice.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I have forſworn
Writing my name, or mark; but I can tell you.—

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Where I may finde this Girl?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: More I can do,
If need require; 'tis in my power to give
Her back to your poſſeſſion, and I am willing.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: An honeſt man.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: On reaſonable conditions,
And ſuch as ſhall not trench on borrowing mony.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Honeſter yet.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: For you ſhall give it freely, and get by it:
Sir, you muſt underſtand, if I do this,
I ſhall betray a friend of mine, that has
Put me in truſt; one that intends to marry her,
D'ye mark? and get three thouſand pound upon her;
One that has lent me ſums too, without parchment,
Or fooliſh circumſtance to be return'd;
VVhich you were never yet ſo much a Chriſtian,
As to be guilty of, in your Uſurers Gallon
Of Conſcience-melting Sack: this deſerves ſomething,
'Tis part of my revenew: younger brothers
Are glad of penſion; it helps to tooke
At Ordinaries, and pay trifling reckonings, that
Ariſe to a bill or tedious circumſtance
Of cleer Orphographie, for Cock and Mallard,
VVhich puts the Bar-boy to Arithmerick,
Becauſe ſome expedition is required;
You have a bond of mine.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: For fifty pounds.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I had but forty, and the Scrivener paid;
VVith whom your worſhip too perhaps divided:
If you remember, there were pretious dinners,
Ere I could count the chickens all together;
Which was your thrift and my expence: you ſhall
Firſt cancel that bond; nay this wo' not do't,
And give, d'ye mark? give me a hundred pieces,
Perhaps I'll drink your health; this ſhall betray
Your Neece again, give her into your hands,
Though for my treachery I be ſung in ballads,
And have the Town-curſe, if I ever marry,
To ſhew my wife can graft well.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: 'Tis too much,
For no more labour, ſir.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: If you conſider,
Two hundred will not bring me to't again:
Thus fair I'll deal with ye, I'll not have a croſs
Till I have don't, but then I will be ſure on't:
Fetch, fetch the buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: The bond is ready.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I will have ready mony too, you have
Bags of all ſizes, and denominations;
Thoſe things do promiſe well,
Now I attend you.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Do this feat for me, and 'tis all thine own.—

div.stage: Enter Juſtice, Playfaire, his Brother, Neece.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: Now we may wiſh you joy, the Prieſt hath tyed
That knot, no ſubtlety nor malice can
Diſſolve; and I repent not I have been
An actor in your Comedy; though I ſhould not
Be temped eaſily to ſuch another
Engagement: for your ſake, I have diſpenc'd with
My perſon and my place.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: You were always
My loving Unkle.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Sir, you have in this
Deſerv'd our lives and fortunes.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: I have plaid
My part too.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Thou haſt ſhewed thy ſelf a Doctor,
VVhich ſhall be a happy Omen to thy ſtudies.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: I have ſhew'd my ſelf a Brother, ſir.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: That name
I muſt know often too.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: Moſt happy in
A vertuous Siſter, I congratulate
Again your wiſh'd enlargement, and the meeting
Of both your loving hearts.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: It was good mirth,
To hear him confident all our device
VVas but a dream.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: He is awake by this time,
Should Lambert fail, we'll have another way
To invite him; and if honeſtie prevail not,
Force ſhame, till he conſent.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Some offenders, ſir,
Are brought to be examined.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: Nephew, withdraw, with your fair Bride; theſe troubles
Are incident to my place, I'll ſoon diſpatch 'em.—

div.stage: Exit Playfaire, Brother, Neece and Servant.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: How now, my Maſters; Maſter Hartwel? ha!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Look on me, ſir, as a delinquent: theſe
Are able to accuſe me.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: VVhat's his offence?

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.l: Nothing but killing of a man.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: VVhat proof?

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.l: He has confeſt it, ſir.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: Miſtreſs Bellamy,
Y'are come in a ſad time; here's Maſter Hartwel
Accus'd for killing.—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: 'Tis not poſſible:
Good ſir, be lieve it not.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: He does confeſs.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: I am not worth your pity, gentle Lady:
In vain I ſhould extenuate my fact,
To ſave the trouble of examinations;
Here I confeſs again my hand is guilty
Of killing him, whoſe feeble arm durſt not
Lift up a weapon to defend himſelf.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: That was not manly.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: I but ſlew a coward ſo,
Startup; and could I call his life again,
I ſhould as ſoon deſtroy it; you perhaps
Know not my provocations; he was
My Rival, ſir: pardon me, Miſtreſs Bellamy,
To whom I only ſeem'd a proſelyte
In love: I had no heart to give from her;
And in my ſtudy to decline your anger,
I fell upon her ſcorn; which in a few minutes
Engag'd me to this fate: nor am I troubled,
That I muſt die; when ſhe upon whoſe faith
I durſt have laid the hopes of my eternity,
Hath violated all the truſt of woman.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.l: Will't pleaſe you, ſir?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: Forbear a little.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Tell me, thou moſt unkind, if thou durſt love
At all; how couldſt thou think I could be ſuch
A deſperate Atheiſt, that thou ſo ſoon,
With ſo ſtrange Apoſtacie, ſhould'ſt revenge it?
Theſe ſwelling drops, which in thy innocence
Might have prevail'd to have reſtor'd the dead,
Heaven now doth look on, and deſpiſe; and though
Thou ſhed moiſt tribute on this tomb, 't ſhall ſlide
Neglected on the marble, and be loſt;
As if the ſtone had ſence, to puniſh thy
Diſdain of me; I can behold thee weeping,
And not be mov'd to wiſh I were not guilty
Of killing him, whoſe love had been thy tryumph;
And I dare boldly ſtill ſtand in the contempt
Of what I am to ſuffer, and the juſtice
Of my own truth: challenge thy ſoul to anſwer,
In what I was beneath that gaudy fool,
Excepting that he had more earth then I
To help his ſcale, which yet he may be in debt for
To his fathers ſins; alive he could not merit
One cold diſdain from thee; and dead, how comes it
He ſhould be worth thy tears? but let thy eyes
Chide this unruly ſorrow: dreſs thy cheeks
With thy freſh blood again and let thy face
Open a book of ſmiles, in the aſſurance
I have not long to live: when I have numbred
A few ſad minutes, thou ſha't be reveng'd,
And I ſhall never trouble thee; if this
Be not enough, extend thy malice further,
And if thou find'ſt one man that lov'd me living,
Will honour this cold body with a grave,
Be cruel, and corrupt his charity:
So fare you well.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Yet you muſt ſtay and hear me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: He ſha'not ſuffer, if my friends or ſtate
Can purchaſe him a pardon: where's the body
Of him that's ſlain?

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.l: We know not, here is all
The free confeſſion of the fact.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: This may
Proceed from diſcontents: life to ſome men
Is but their torment, in whoſe pain they will
As on the rack, often confeſs what never
VVas in their thought.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Speak it again, and I
Dare promiſe thee to live.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: My heart was ever
Conſtant, my mothers love was but thy tryal,
As mine, a ſeeming change in thy diſguiſe,
Applied by thy too tender apprehenſion;
The words were, I would chuſe my husband here:
But what will this avail us?

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Maſter Juſtice, I here diſcharge you.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: My joy obeys
No limits, I accus'd my ſelf unjuſtly:
Startup's alive.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Nay I know not that:
My ſervant's with him; but if he have plaid
The hangman, ſtarv'd or ſmother'd him in a ditch,
I have made fair work.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: This were a welcome truth.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sir, the Conſtable.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: I had rather it had been Lambert and the Uſurer.
But wait, and give me knowledge when they come.—

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Where's Maſter Juſtice?

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Ha! 'tis he and Cloſe,
Then I am ſecure, your pardon and thy love.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You have it freely, and a mothers prayers
For both your happineſs.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.l: Pleaſe your worſhip, I have brought before you two
vagrants that we took laſt night i'th' field, between one and
two a clock in the morning; very ſuſpicious vagrants; and by
my own authority, I condemn'd 'em becauſe it was late.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Shall we be hang'd, Cloſe? we are condemn'd already.

sp.speaker: Conſt.
sp.p: Coming this morning to the priſon, I found them drinking away ſorrow in double juggs, to the very ſtaggering of my authority: I beſeech your worſhip to draw a pair of Mittens for 'em both; for they deſerve to be made ſamplers, and whipt for the edification of the Common-wealth.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: This is the Gentleman was kill'd, ſir.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: No, ſir,
Not kill'd outright, but I was almoſt ſtarv'd
With cold; theſe Gent lewomen know me,
And I ſhould know that hoſe and doublet;
Thoſe garments that you wear, I oft have ſeen.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Well ſaid Jeronymo.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: I was fain to borrow
Theſe of a priſoner, that lies in upon
A diamond.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: Officers you are diſcharg'd—

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: And we too?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: Yes, and joy in every boſom.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Cloſe, you muſt know this Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: My wife, ſir.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: It is enough for you to know her, ſir,
And me to acknowledge.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.l: D'ye know me, ſir?

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Yes, and your daughter too:
Who brought you to town?

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.l: And you ſhall right her.

sp.speaker: Star.
sp.l: Is ſhe grown crooked? pox on her, I know too well:
Peace, not a word more, I know your meaning,
Do not diſcredit me, and we'll ſteal down
And marry her, ere any be aware on't:
I wo'not ſtay to ſhift me, take no leave:
The jeſt will be, when I am in the Country,
How like an Aſs he'll look on my apparel.—

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sir, Maſter Lambert, and if I be not
Miſtaken, the Uſurer Hornet very gallant.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: I muſt entreat your patience a while;
You'll meet with friends i'the next room.—

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Excuſe
Our boldneſs, ſir, this gentleman.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: I ſhould know him:
Maſter Hornet, you are very welcome.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Good ſir,
No ceremony, we are come to you
'Bout buſineſs: I have loſt my Neece, and would
Know where ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: D'ye take me for a Wizzard?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: With your favour, our deſires are that you would
Be witneſs to a bargain, and receive
Some trifles, ſir, in truſt to be delivered
To me, if I reſtore his kinſwoman.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Not elſe, on that condition I depoſite
Theſe hundred pieces and a bond; if he
Deliver me my Neece, they are his fraught;
If not, they call me owner.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Pardon, ſir,
That I preſume to bring this trouble to ye.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: 'Tis none at all.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You ſha'not expect long;
So reſt you merry.—

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: How fare you, ſir?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: As you ſee, faln away an inch ſince morning;
But this will phyſick me: if I poſſeſs
This harlotry again, I'll make her ſure:
Truſt not a woman, they have found the herb
To open locks, not braſen towers can hold 'em:
Or if they get not looſe, they have the vertue
Of Load ſtones ſhut up in a box; they'll draw
Cuſtomers to 'em; nay being dead and buryed,
There is ſuſpition they will break the grave;
Which puts ſo many husbands to the charge
Of heavie ſtones, to keep their bad wives under.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: You are mov'd.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Oh Maſter Juſtice, you are honeſt:
I have been abus'd, ſo miſerably cheated,
I am aſham'd to think on't: ſtay, what Muſick?—
Ha! 'tis my Neece; the very, very ſame.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: There, ſir, you have her, and the reſt is mine.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Take it—And you ſhall go along with me.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: How, Unkle!
A reveller? you'll lead me a Coranto.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: You ſhall dance homewards.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: What make you ſo familiar with my wife?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Ha! wife! is ſhe married?

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: 'Tis upon record,
I'll bring a Parſon that ſhall take his oath on't.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Give me my bond and mony, Maſter Juſtice:
Where? where?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Here, but they are not to be recover'd
By law: I have a judgement, ſir, againſt you.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: You have conſpir'd, to rob, cheat and undo me:
You ſhall be all 〈◊〉 -Chamber'd.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: Sir, be calm, and hear us.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I'll hear nothing.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Yes, you ſhall,
It will be neceſſary: I am bold,
Perſuming on her favorit to 〈◊〉
A parcel of three thouſand pound; the ſum
Belongs to me by vertue of a marriage,
And I muſt have it.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Vertue of a marriage?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: I ſaw the Prieſt conjoyn their hands; he will
Deſerve your love.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Perhaps you may continue
A thouſand, or two thouſand on ſecurity.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: What perſecution this?

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: Faith ſir conſider,
'Tis more ſafe to ſee her thus beſtowed,
Then truſt a Jury; if the Doctor had
Given her too much Opium, or purg'd
Her ſoul away, things might go worſe: but I'll
Keep counſel.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: So, ſo, have ye mortified me yet?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: For your own ſake, and as you are a true knight,
I'll tell no tales.

div.stage: Enter Miſtreſs Bellamy, Frances, Hartwel and Cloſe.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Now have ye done?—The widow,
Not a word more: take her, I'll pay you, ſir,
Three thouſand pound to morrow: Noble widow,
You were in the firſt liſt to be invited;
My Neece I told you of, is married to
This worthy Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You look like a bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: 'Tis in your power to make it good, what ſay you?
Shall we joyn iſſue?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I will never marry.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: You are reſolv'd, why ſo? come hither Nephew,
Sha't be my heir, I love thee for thy wit;
But charm thy friends, they do not laugh at me:
I'll be a knight too, if I live, and build
An Hoſpital for twenty more o'th' Order;
Which I'll reduce my ſelf, out of the Suburbs,
In women's petticoats, and turn Squires again
To Whores, or Paraſites to Noblemen,
For want of fit proviſion.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: An excellent
Foundation: but where's Startup?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Sunk, I think.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: Ne'er conjure for him: we are ingrateful to
Our bliſs, for waſting of theſe pretious minutes,
Which are ſo many ages, till the Church
Hath made us perfect.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Is there any more work
For the Prieſt? then give you joy beforehand,
And let us celebrate the day together.

sp.speaker: Cloſe.
sp.l: I am glad of your converſion, y'are the firſt
Jew, that in my remembrance has turn'd Chriſtian.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: Walk on to joyes;
Twixt Love and Fortune, now th' accompts are even.

sp.speaker: Hart.
sp.l: A chain of Hearts, and the firſt linck in Heaven.

l.hi: THrough many hazards, Love hath found a way
For Friends to meet: good Omen to our Play.
If love hath brought you hither, Gentlemen,
Love will find out the way to come agen.
And we dare promiſe, if you relliſh theſe,
Our Loves ſhall find out other ways to pleaſe.

div.p: There is lately Printed two excellent Comedies, entituled, The Old Couple: By Thomas May Eſquire.
The City-Night-Cap, or Crede quod habes & habes. By Robert Davenport.
Both theſe, with variety of other Playes, are to be ſold by Samuel Speed, at the Printing Preſs in St. Pauls Church-Yard. 1661.
